item.description:
"Battle of Shanghai" reproduces two Shanghai incidents of different nature in completely different game systems.

The "First Shanghai Incident" is a zonal wargame that represents the military scalade that ensued the January Incident, in 1932. One player plays with the japanese army and the other plays the Kuomintang Armed Forces. The game is played in only two turns, one for february and one for march. Each turn both players alternate in taking actions by expending logistic points until they exhaust their points or both players passes consecutively.
The map depicts the countryside north of Shanghai, in a zonal map. The goal of the Japanese is to score enought victory points by occupying some key areas by the end of each turn or else eliminate all KMT troops from around Shanghai. The KMT wins elseway. The counters represent regiments or brigades, with few support counters.

In "Shanghai / Nanjing Operation", is a more classical wargame, that simulates the 1938 thrust to Nanjing. The map represents the region between Shanghai and Nanjing, and it's an hexagon's map. The units are at divisional level for the japanese and at army level for the Kuomingtang.
Each player starts with 7 X-shaped tiles. On your turn you add a tile. If your tile has two matching borders, you may play another. It's a race to get rid of your tiles first.

Description from the publisher:

Activity has been around for more than 25 years, and Activity Multi Challenge is the latest version of the game, with players winning or losing together!

In this communication game, players on the team need to guess six terms before time runs out, and you need to plan well since 24 cards must be finished in order to win the game. Things to be guessed come in fifteen categories, and in addition to mentioning these categories to help others guess the hidden term, you can draw activity coins in order to give additional clues, with ten different types of activities being possible, from rhyming to alliteration to pantomiming to talking backwards and more.

Description from the publisher:

The dice in Bumpi are unique in that they do not roll on the table; they bounce! This is because the dice are actually five-sided objects in which four of the sides are attached to the fifth, and to "roll" the die, you push it down onto the table, flattening all the sides, then let it spring up to roll around.

Why are you doing this? Because all players are presented with a task card at the start of each round. Sometimes you want to find an animal, sometimes a color, and often both — and you need to keep rolling until someone finds a solution and wins the card. Whoever collects five cards first wins the game!

name.value: Trivial Pursuit: Star Wars – The Black Series Edition

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

This Star Wars the Black Series edition of the Trivial Pursuit game gives players a chance to imagine that they are Jedi Masters of trivia! In this edition, players can recall favorite movie moments from the entire Star Wars saga including Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The game includes 1,800 questions in 6 Star Wars themed categories: The Cantina, The Force, Heroes, Villains and Scoundrels, The Saga, A Galaxy Far, Far Away, and Hyperspace. Players choose their allegiance and move around the board with a Jedi, Rebel Alliance, First Order, or Galactic Empire sculpted mover. The first player to collect all 6 wedges and answer the final question correctly wins.

item.description:
In Sheep Sheep, players are trying to collect the most sheep of a particular color.

Each turn, a player has 1 minute and 30 seconds to exchange sheep from their own line of 4 with one from the 3x3 common area. Once time's up, they collect all the sheep in a row and/or column that have the same color in the common area and tuck them under their own personal goal sheep. They are then replaced with ones from the draw deck.

At the end of the game, players tally up their score. Every sheep they've collected is worth 1 point but those that match their goal card are worth 2. Whoever has the most points wins.

In Ultraz, you're a team captain. Build your team of 15 Ultraz and defeat your opponent.

On your side, you'll have 6 active cards. The front 3 cards serve as offense while the back 3 serve as defense. With these cards, you'll attempt to pass, black and shoot.

First person to 3 points wins the game.

Coffee Game is a paper and pencil game where there will be all winners and one loser. The loser have to pay a coffee or whatever you want. ;-) A random player, called the writer, write an hidden number from 1 to 999. The player on his left start the game calling a number from 1 to 999 trying to not guess the written number. The writer tell if the number is higher or lower to the written number. The next player have to call a number in the remain range trying to not guess the written number. The writer tell if the called number is higher or lower to the written number. The range will always be lower. If the turn come back to the writer he have to call a -2 or +2 from the last called number. Who guess the number lost the game.
Example of play. 4 player A, B, C and D. A is the writer. A write 334 hidden. B have to call a number from 1 to 999. B call 562. Higher. C have to call a number from 1 to 562. C call 275. Lower. D have to call a number from 275 to 562. D call 499. Higher. A, the writer, have to call a -2 number from the last call (499). A call 497. Higher. B have to call a number from 275 to 497. B call 330. Lower. C have to call a number from 330 to 497. C call 399. Higher. D have to call a number from 330 to 399. D call 331. Lower. A, the writer, have to call a +2 number from last called 331. A call 333. Lower. B have to call a number from 333 to 399. B call 340. Higher. C have to call a number from 333 to 340. C call 334. Guessed. C lost the game and have to pay a coffee.

Description from the publisher:

Space stations equipped with high-performance solar panels called Solaris circle red giants and send the generated energy directly to Earth using new laser and wormhole technology. In the science-fiction space game Solaris, players try to solar mine the suns of other galaxies.

Solaris is a strategy game with many tactical choices won by the player who manages the tight resources the best.

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Austria in all its facets is at the center of Challenge Austria. From landscape to music, history to sport, one should not only have their red-white-red knowledge up to date, but also be ready to shine in their negotiation skills since questions are not only answered, but also bought and exchanged. During the game, players have a number of question cards in their possession and can answer only those about Austria as a whole and those about the region of the country in which their game figure is currently located. Thus, you might want to trade cards with others, offer them cash, move to new locations, or pay to return cards that are too difficult to answer. Too pay too much, though, for in the end the first player to collect a previously agreed upon sum of money wins the game.

Chickens and foxes are at play in Chicken out!, with players taking turns revealing cards from their decks, adding (or subtracting) values to a generally escalating sum, and hoping not to exceed 21 because then the active player has to take all the revealed cards. Players can choose to chicken out and not risk failure, but sometimes you'll need to take a chance to win.

Four kinds of foxes lie in wait among the cards, and they can mix up the revealed sum, counting as the last number played, escalating the sum to 20, or resetting the sum to zero to start the tension rising all over again. Play out all your cards to win!

item.description: In Circo Delfino, players want to find the right combinations of colored dolphins as quickly as possible — sometimes even combining primary-colored dolphins to make secondary-colored ones! — in order to collect more cards than anyone else.

In Das Spiel mit dem Essen, players move their pieces around the plate on the game board that's divided into different food groups and attempt to answer food-related questions in order to win chips — and no, not potato chips, but point chips!

name.value: Alice in Wonderland: A Curious Collection of Puzzles

item.description:
A trivia game where players earn points by answering themed questions on their turn.

On their turn a player picks a card from one of four difficulty piles. Scoring points for the difficulty of the card if they answer correctly. Play continues until a player accumulates an agreed upon number of points.

Each player has an "Eat Me" and "Drink Me" card which they may play to alter the score of a given card in accordance to the instructions on the "Eat Me"/"Drink Me" card.

The game is a handheld dome containing 15 dice (5 red, 5 yellow, 5 blue) and whose base contains a 4x4 grid of slots for the dice to settle into.

The object is to shake and rattle the dome so that 4 dice of the same color form a straight line or a square. You score the sum of the numbers on the dice in that line or square. A diagonal counts double, and a center square counts triple.

The main characters in Dragoonies have discovered a treasure chest and naturally each of them wants to take as much of the gold as possible for themselves — but to do that, they need to solve tasks more quickly than anyone else.

At the start of play, a circle of sixteen dragon cards is formed in the center of the table; each card is different from each other, whether due to color, horns, or small objects with which they're equipped. On a turn, the active player reveals 2-6 search cards — with more cards making for a tougher challenge — then all the players race to determine the characteristics that are most common on the search cards, e.g., the color blue, a key, or three horns. Multiple solutions might exist, and when you find one, you want to cover an unoccupied dragon card that corresponds to the answer. If you do so correctly, you earn a Drachentaler, and whoever collects the most money in the end wins!

Let's go to the amusement park! Instead of simply gawking at the attractions, however, the players in Gho...Gho...Ghosty get to command their own ghost train, competing against others to travel far and nab the most passengers. Players take turns in the role of Mr. Ghosty, collecting two cards from the ghost train card display. When the ghost train reaches a certain length, the train takes off — and when all 75 wagons are gone, the best ghost train boss will be determined based on the passengers they have.

Description from the publisher:

Orange Toss is a fast-thinking, unpredictable adult party game. How fast can you come up with an answer before the Orange Timer 
runs out? Don't get caught with your peel down! The player left holding the Orange Timer when the time runs out collects the card. The player with the fewest cards at the end of 13 rounds wins!

Yikes! All the foliage in the forest has been stirred up by a violent gust of wind, and 36 little critters have lost their shelter. Equipped with the appropriate leaf cards, the players in Insectini need to hide the insects again leaf by leaf as quickly as possible. To do this, they need to spot the tiny details on these critters — a light bulb on a firefly, a grub playing the guitar, a caterpillar munching on a snack — and cover them with a matching leaf in their hand.

King John is having a party with lots of guests. Unfortunately he's terrible at remembering the faces of those guests, so he needs your help.

In the game King John, four cards are revealed at the table each round, with each card showing some combination of characters. The active player shows these cards to all, then hides them and rolls dice to determine whether the other players are searching for a particular character or the character who appears most (or least) often on the cards.

item.description:
In Memo-Palace, players will first hide the animal tiles in the castle, but they won't just place the tiles and leave it at that. No, they must tell a story about each animal as they place it, with all the players paying attention to the stories.

Once all the animals have been placed, players must then attempt to find matching pairs of animals in the castle, but they also need to combine the two stories for the two tiles that they find, and if they don't remember the stories, then they must return the tiles. Thus, Memo-Palace combines storytelling and memory in a new way to create a fresh challenge and experience for young players each game.

item.description:
In Pixbox, the active player lays out six transparent cards at random. These cards show one or more blue squares on them, with the squares arranged in various patterns. The player then lays out a red task card, and everyone must visualize — without touching the blue cards! — how they could arrange one or more blue cards in an overlapping manner, but with only the transparent areas covering one another, so as to recreate the image shown on the red task card.

As soon as a player thinks they have a solution, they yell out and attempt to demonstrate their idea with the transparent cards. If they're correct, they keep the cards they used, and whoever collects the most points wins.

On a turn, a player reveals two of the tiles; if they match (animal or pattern, which is desired), then they turn over a third tile. If that tile matches as well, they earn a point, and whoever earns five points first wins.

item.description: Zebulon: Galactic Control is a space themed strategic board game that allows you to create a new layout every time you play using 40 planets on 20 tiles. Complete missions, lay traps and confront other players in battle. Players race around the map by purchasing fuel en route to completing missions. When you finish a mission pick up rewards and upgrade your ship. Use reward cards to attack your foe or help you win the game.
Object is to line up 3 cards of the same colour, and three cards of the same insect.

Description from the publisher:

Critter Combat is a 2 - 4 player battle and capture card game with cool critters that have even cooler abilities. This game is played with one of 4 included 26 card decks, and a set of 18 habitat cards. Play your cards for abilities to set back your enemy or bolster your positions, use them to capture habitats, or take on your opponent in adorable battle.

Your army of fuzzy critters has been pushed too far! Take your cute, furry, and fuzzy animals to war on a no–holds–barred mission to destroy, decimate, and humiliate your enemies. Take back the trees and land that are rightfully, and not so rightfully, yours!

Introduction

Linage is a finite territory game for two players: Vertical and Horizontal. It's played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty square board. Both players must have access to a shared pool of identical stones.

				
					Definitions

A region is a maximal set of orthogonally contiguous empty points.

A line is a set of three orthogonally contiguous empty points on the same row or column.

A region is owned by Vertical if it contains no horizontal lines, and by Horizontal if it contains no vertical lines. A region is free if it's owned by neither player.

				
					Play

Vertical plays first, then turns alternate. On their turn, a player must either pass or place a stone on an empty point which is part of a free region. At all times, every region must include at least one line.

When both players pass in succession, the game ends. A player's score is the number of points in the regions that they own, plus a komi (see below) in the case of Horizontal. The player with the highest score wins.

				
					Komi

The komi is the number of points which is added to Horizontal's score at the end of the game as a compensation for playing second. Before the game starts, the first player chooses the value of komi, and then the second player chooses sides. To avoid ties, it is suggested that komi be of the form n + 0.5, where n is a whole number.

item.description: Subterranean Cities is played in four rounds, during which players will take turns placing one of their three crew members in their ship to add and activate ship part tiles. These parts are used to maneuver the ship and collect more parts. Victory points are earned by building your ship, and refurbishing ship parts into structures. The player with the most Victory Points at the end of the final round is the winner.

This game kit published by Bruce Moore covers all aspects of 1942 battles in the Pacific. Air to Air, Air to Surface (fixed installations and naval task forces), Naval Surface and Land Combat are all treated as well as multi-player strategic combat embracing all of the above. Scenarios are included for the significant engagements as well as several hypothetical meetings, for example, War Plan Orange III battleship duels and surface action off Malaya had Prince of Wales and Repulse escaped air strikes.

The game kit aspect is the supply of hundreds of small coloured blocks to which unit details must be glued. Torpedo tracks and cloud formations for strategic game weather handling must be cut out.

Math Fluxx is all about the numbers. Players use positive integers (whole numbers) in their quest to achieve a very mathematical goal — but it's not just putting 4 and 2 together to achieve the 42 goal (for example) as Math Fluxx also features the Plan B Meta Rule. Plan B puts special victory rules into play which give you a second way to win and require even more arithmetical acumen (e.g., "Plus Victory" lets you win if your keepers add up to the current goal). With Math Fluxx, the fun is exponential!

item.description:
Theme: For the tricky little mouse to get into any one of his three cheese holes without being caught by the fast sly cat
Game Play: Mouse is moved by using magnetic "mouse" wand underneath the game board. Cat is moved by using magnetic "cat" wand across the top of the game board. Start the cat on one of the starting circles, the mouse is placed in the other starting circle. The game starts when the mouse player says "go". Cat scores when he catches (touches) the mouse anywhere on the board. Mouse scores when he eludes the cat and enters any one of the three cheese holes. As mouse and cat score, they advance one square on the scoring board. After each time the cat or mouse score the players switch, mouse becomes cat, cat becomes mouse. First to score 6 times and land on the house on scoring board wins.

Theme: Be the player to put the final piece of the puzzle together.
Game Play: Pick a puzzle friend and place it on the gear space with the same color as your friend. Spin the spinner and move your friend to the color the spinner lands on. If you land on a space with a puzzle piece place the puzzle piece in the puzzle tray. 
Game ends: When the final puzzle piece is placed in the puzzle tray.

Description from the publisher:

Ritual is a strategic tile-laying game of magical dominance for two to five players. In Ritual you take on the role of a powerful wizard joining with other wizards to perform an intricate ritual of magic. Being a wizard, you must take this opportunity to prove once and for all that YOU are the best wizard by having the most influence over the ritual at its completion.

At its heart Ritual is about three things: tiles, runes and influence. Being a tile-laying game, Ritual’s core mechanic revolves around drawing hexagonal tiles one at a time from a common pool known as the ley line and placing them onto the scroll that serves as the board.

Each tile has three parts know as rune pieces. Throughout the game players try to match up identical rune pieces in groups of three known as runes. Runes players create can be activated to cause powerful effects capable of reshaping the board, but such power comes at a cost: influence. Each player gets a set of colored cubes known as influence cubes. These cubes are not only used to activate runes, but also to determine where you can play on the scroll and to tally your final score. Clever use of tiles, runes and influence is essential to winning a game of Ritual.

Ritual’s simple gameplay, deep strategy and beautiful presentation make it a fun game for beginners and experienced board-gamers alike.

name.value: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York – "Talking" Electronic Game

item.description:
Theme: Harry and Marv chase Kevin, with actual situations from the movie.
Game Play: As Harry and Marv get closer, Kevin taunts them by saying 3 different phrases. Draw a card and move characters according to the color spaces and traps on the card. If the burglars catch Kevin they win the round.

A fast paced card game where players try to score the least points at the end of the game. The game ends once a player is down to two cards. Points are the number of cards in each player's hand plus 'It's Not Your Turn' cards. 
 Players take turns either playing the correct card from their hand (if they have it) face-up, playing a card face-down in an attempt to either bluff or reverse-bluff, or being honest about not having the right card and taking a 'It's Not Your Turn' card. Players can even use a house rule where they can try to steal another player's turn(s) by playing certain number cards at the right moment.
 The game has a lighthearted spoof theme of the stereotypical gamer elitist as shown on the different suit cards and on the game box.

"The game the world watches you can now play"

Provides entertainment for all soccer fans.

The object of the game is to be the first person to make their way around the board, answering as many questions correct as possible and making the least amount of errors.

Players roll dice and move along a round, soccer ball shaped playing board. Players then answer soccer based trivia questions, collecting goal tokens for correct answers. Make a mistake or commit a foul though, and you could end up with a yellow or red card!

Description from the back of the box:

The following questions are an example of what you'll find:

 Who won the World Cup in 1934?
 Which country does Roberto Baggio play for?
 What shape is a soccer ball?




The answers are made up of:

 multiple choice
 true or false
 plus some real brain teasers




Included in V.N.J's World Soccer:

 A round playing board
 6 player tokens
 6 plastic player holders
 1 playing dice
 70 goal tokens
 22 red cards
 22 yellow cards
 330 question and answer cards




This board game is made in Australia by:

V.N.J. World SOccer
Tapleys Hill Road, West Beach
South Australia, 5024, AUSTRALIA

On Planeta ZwierzÄ…t ('Animal Planet') you will encounter various species of animals. Try to determine their characteristics and guess on which continent they live. But you have to avoid the hunter. And better not call the wolf out of the woods.

The aim of the players is the assignment of animal cards to the appropriate continents and prioritize them according to the values of their characteristics. The game allows you to explore the characteristics and habitat of 110 species of animals.

In Axio, players take turns adding tiles to a shared playing area. Each time you play a tile — with tiles bearing one or two colored symbols — you score points for symbols of the same type that are in rows extending from the recently-placed tile. Tiles can be placed on other tiles in some situations.

When the game ends, players check the scores for each of their symbols, and their final score is equal to the lowest value among them. Whichever player has the highest low score wins!

item.description: Maybe the most recognizable walker on the planet today, the Mickey chassis has given birth to a huge range of machines build on its rugged chassis. In the Pacific or the Middle-East, the Allies use a tropical version of the same chassis, whose main feature is an open top turret. The deadliest arsenal of the Mickey family stays the same. The Steel Rain mounts an impressive gun, capable of blowing any ground target on the planet to pieces.

Description from the publisher:

In Piñata Loca' we are filling up Piñatas with tasty candies and toys. But sometimes we secretly put useless objects inside the Piñata too. Hit the right Piñata and collect as many tasty candies and toys as possible.
 
Players try to collect sweets and toys (positive points) and give useless objects (negative points) to their opponents, by wisely playing their cards, on columns that represent Piñatas. When a player places the 7th card, then that Piñata and he collects all of its cards. 
 
Your intuition, observation, strategy and logic skills will guide you to the most... 
“PIÑATA LOCA”!

item.description:
In Tudor, you are a Lord in the court of King Henry VIII. Here you will be positioning your Courtiers among the influential Lords who grant you actions that allow you to maneuver your family members to high title offices and gain their respective Rings of prestige and power.

Players take turns placing their Courtiers into the three Audience Chambers, each with unique actions. Then each player will place their one Lord in a Chamber of their choice. Only Courtiers in an Audience Chamber with any player's Lord present will be able to use that Chamber’s actions. But be careful, since there are only a limited number of seats available in each Chamber and competing families can push you out of a Chamber!

Then all player Courtiers, in Chambers with a Lord, take turns performing ONE of the two Actions in their Chambers. The powerful Lords may also take both actions in the Chamber they occupy. Chamber Actions allow you to gain Court Cards and to move your Courtiers in the Throne Room onto spaces with square Court Tokens that represent various faction interests and demands at the court. You collect these Court Tokens, which are one way to gain Prestige at court.

When you reach the top space of a Court Office in the Royal Court, you will gain that title - represented by a Ring. A player's Rings are placed and displayed on their individual Player Hand Screens. Positioning your Rings on different fingers project your interests, intent, and inclinations to the other players, because different positions enhance specific Actions that your Courtiers take in the Audience Chambers!

You must always be vigilant, because another players can seize your Court Office, kicking your Office Holder out in disgrace and then taking one of YOUR Rings!

The player with the most prestige at game end wins!

In each game of Tudor, you will choose to play one of many scenario cards, each with their own special rules that can alter the game in dramatic ways. In addition, choose two different scoring cards to vary gameplay, creating a strategic experience with exceptional replayability.

—description from the publisher

link.value: テンデイズゲームズ (Ten Days Games)

item.description:
Up to two thousand pounds in weight and over ten feet tall, the bear is considered the biggest and heaviest terrestrial carnivore in the world. Of course, there is not just "one bear"; on the contrary, there are plenty of subspecies that differ from each other in various aspects. For instance, only the Kodiak bear (ursus arctos middendorffi) weighs about 2,000 lbs. The polar bear (ursus maritimus) weighs "only" 1,100 lbs., but gets much bigger than the Kodiak bear, being as much as 11 ft. tall!

Bärenpark takes you into the world of bears, challenging you to build your own bear park. Would you like another polar bear enclosure or rather a koala* house? The park visitors are sure to get hungry on their tour through the park, so build them places to eat! Whatever your choices are, make sure you get the next building permit and use your land wisely! (* No, koalas aren't bears but they're so cute, we couldn't leave them out of this game!)

In more detail, each player in Bärenpark builds their own bear park, attempting to make it as beautiful as they can, while also using every square meter possible. The park is created by combining polyomino tiles onto a grid, with players scoring for animal houses, outdoor areas, completed construction, and more. The sooner you build it, the better! Cover icons to get new tiles and park sections. The game ends as soon as one player has finished expanding their park, then players tally their points to see who has won.

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
In this game you are scouting band members to create cool and exciting bands. You will then help these bands debut, making a name for themselves, before your talent agency runs out of money. Of course, you will also be aiming to get these bands in to perform at the legendary Namidano Festival, on that famed stage that people are always talking about.

Namidano Festival is a band management card game in which you will rely on your assessment of possibilities as well as your luck with timing. Players will take on the role of talent management, working within the limits of their hand of cards, efficiently building bands in order to build the reputation of their talent agency. Along the way, you will be managing your bands, getting them into events, and hopefully the festival itself, scoring points along the way.

link.value: 大気圏内ゲームズ (Taikikennai Games)
